reviewText: I had read reviews prior to renting the film, so I wasn't surprised by the quality and intelligence of the characters. I was looking for something thought-provoking and I found it in "Strapped". The main character leads a difficult life. He responds to his client's needs both mentally and physically. He is the person they need him to be. You don't feel very sorry for him though. He seems to enjoy his life. He doesn't run from encounters, though he does seem to ask himself," What am I doing here?" more than once as the movie progresses. Each encounter seems to force him to reflect on himself. He doesn't seem to dislike what he finds, either. In the end he has a lightbulb moment, but then the movie is over, leaving the audience with questions as to exactly how this changes his life.Overall I recommend the movie highly. It's one that you can watch several times to pick up symbolism and imagery that was missed the previous viewing.

reviewText: It was actually a rather good movie. The ending was a little cheesy, but overall good.The changes in the main character happened somewhat abruptly with each "encounter" he makes, but given the time limits of the film, this is understandable.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is almost a genre unto itself. It has enough air of mystery to be engaging but there are no cheap plot devices. The hustler's progression through several different lives in one night is beautiful, erotic, touching and jarring. It is fairly explicit without descending into pure erotica. The most beautiful man in the film is the oldest, giving the lie to the notion that all gay actors are hardbodied young stereotypes. It reminded me of a curiosity cabinet where there is something new behind every door. This and "Leather Jacket Love Story" are in my pantheon of the most superb gay films.
summary: Well Crafted, Well Acted and Haunting
Title: N/A

reviewText: Another reviewer said that they had skipped on this movie because the trailer made it appear sleazy, I am ashamed to admit that I too judged this "book by it's cover" and it took me a while to give it a chance. I am so glad that I just threw my hands in the air and said to hell with it. I netflixed the movie and it was a terrific film.  It was brilliant, how the apartment building was a world in and of itself that managed to incorporate a variety of gay types of men.  There was the masculine unsure gay man, then there were the outrageous queens, and then the self loathing gay man living a lie, next was the supportive old gay, and finally the perfect guy -the one that fits and clicks.I loved this movie so much, I couldnt help but to fall in love with the Hustler, he was so kind (playing his part to perfection I guess) but he was really cool and just kick back. He didnt seem bitter or jaded at all.  He was just the perfect (I dont want to say prostitute) but he was just good at it. He was very malleable and able to adjust to any situation. He was good at reading people.  This is a great movie, I cant wait to own it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Strapped is an interesting indie film about a good-looking hustler who has many memorable experiences on one fateful night. Here is a gay film that is sexy, well-acted, and eventually romantic. There are some scenes that move too slowly, and times when I didn't know where the movie was going. And although the film's third act is romantic, it's also somewhat sappy for a movie that started off dark and edgy.. Still, Strapped is worth seeing if you like challenging independent movies.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'll be honest; I expected "Strapped" to be watchable at best. It just has so many things going against it on paper. Writers, directors, and actors that most people wouldn't know and very few theatrical screenings as well (it got at least one screening though since the NY Times gave it a mini review). Every now and then you get a real out of nowhere surprise with, but most of the time films like this end up collecting dust until it's officially lost in time with the other rubbish nobody knows exists. However, "Strapped" definitly isn't one of those films. I was actually blown away how good this one was. With over 100 reviews on here; it seems other people have taken notice as well.The plot centers around a young hustler who's trying to make it out of an apartment building on a rainy evening. However it's easier said than done, and soon he has multiple encounters with the many gay men who live there. Is everything what it seems, or is something more going on? "Strapped" does a fantastic job of keeping the audience wondering that throughout. I won't spoil the end, but I will say that I was really pleased by it. It's surprising, and it isn't at the same time. What is definitly surprising though is how well done it all is. Ben Bonenfant (who's actually straight) is fantastic as the lead (seriously, the guy can act), and all the encounters he has are compelling, and feel completely genuine (and even sometimes loving). The writing and directing are also top notch, and all the supporting actors do a really good job too. The film is also sexy, but not in an explicit way. There's some nudity, but it is all about the discussions the actors have with each other, and their faces when they're having sex. It isn't about how much skin is being shown.Overrall there's just alot to love about this one. It may not be as well known as many other films, but who cares? So much crap comes out of Hollywood every week, and it's great to have such good indie films like this as a way to enjoy cinema when your local theater is full of garbage.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Gay life isn't easy or pretty the only ones that have happiness are young, quite good looking and appear to be gifted then somewhere along the way the worm turns and your old and its all over!!!!!  This movie tells of a journey of one individual who is street smart but not quite yet jaded and quickly seems to learn to be realistic.  The sexual process turns into a unexpected need for affection.  The story is a progression in a learning process that is real and, pardon the pun, not a fairy tale.  Its sad but for many it tells it like it is with no sugar coating.  If you don't mind a tear once in a while and have no aversion to the truth you will like this movie.  I wish gay life had a most happy ending but for many it doesn't.
summary: Excellent representation of how it is
Title: N/A

reviewText: An ambitious young street hustler goes to a trick's apartment in a large inner-city apartment building. After they finish, he can't find his way out of the building, but soon encounters a diverse group of other residents, all of whom are also in the market for something that he can offer.  He professionally and efficiently does what he does best: provide the fantasy they want, gets his money, and moves on to someone else.  But his final encounter in the building is with a young man who wants something Alex has never considered he is capable of providing, at any price: affection and emotional intimacy.I "passed" on this originally, based on the trailer (which makes it look a bit sleazy), but picked it up based on a friend's recommendation.  And I'm glad I did.  Writer/director Joseph Graham offers a surprisingly intelligent and thought-provoking look at intimacy, via a pivotal day in the life of a young man who provides physical intimacy to strangers for a price, but has never really considered his own sexuality leading to any relationship.  As the hustler, newcomer Ben Bonenfant is absolutely riveting with a natural sexiness coupled with intelligence and a significant dose of cynicism.  DVD has several extras (including a seemingly unscripted, lengthy solo commentary by Bonenfant, with his thoughts on the role and the film.), not rated (but would be a solid R for lengthy scenes of simulated gay sex).  Check this one out. Five stars out of five.
summary: Unexpectedly intelligent and thought provoking film.

reviewText: The story grabs you and makes you think about what being gay really is and what that really means. Ben Bonenfant is a wonderful, good-looking and sexy actor with a sincerity and boyishness about him that is hard to duplicate in modern film and also in this genre. The scenarios that he as the lead character encounters in an obviously gay-occupied apartment building highlight the charming and not so charming options gay life represents for modernity, not to mention for a gay escort. This film belongs in your collection, and after watching it, you won't soon forget it.

reviewText: Writer/director Joseph Graham's film is a surprising treat. The story is interesting, different and well acted.  The film's main character, played exceptionally well by Ben Bonenfant, is at the same time manipulative, naive, self-assured and vulnerable.  He is damaged goods, but appears to be functioning fairly well considering.  The film seems careful not to glorify or romanticize the character's profession, but you can't help but notice that he is not a dirty meth head like I would imagine many male prostitutes to be.  He is cheerful, clean and bright and doesn't use drugs, which to me seemed a bit unbelievable.  Though the scene involving the 3 friends was rather weak, I nevertheless, enjoyed the film, came to care about the main character -- as well as several of the supporting players -- and would certainly recommend it.
summary: A really good low budget flick

reviewText: What a wonderful film! This is a very smart and well-crafted little film that rises way above its indie budget. The screenplay crackles and shines and the story/direction move it at the right pace. This is just the sort of film that should be winning awards and recognition outside the GLBT community. It is far superior to much of the "mainstream" tired old product out there. Ah, if more folks weren't scared to expose themselves to something outside their narrow experience... Ben Bonenfant is a real find. He has charisma and delivers his performance and lines in just the most effective way he could. Do not overlook Raphael Barker in a strong supporting performance as someone who lets us see he is smarter and sadder than he at first seems. The role could have been a stereotype but Barker makes it special.
summary: A Little Film That Could and Did!

reviewText: The apartment building he seems trapped in may be a maze or a labyrinth, but it is a good metaphor for a mind -- where most of us are trapped.  He - Adam - seems like a ghost doomed to roam forever in the world of his mind, avoiding love until it rescues him.  The movie is not pretentious or scary, just wholesome and lovely, as Adam slowly allows someone to live in his mind with him.

reviewText: I ordered "Strapped" based on reviews from others and just received it today.  Having just finished it tonight, I now wish it had been on Blu-Ray, but honestly, once I hit Play, I never until now thought about it.  For the first 10-20 minutes, I thought it was going to be disappointing and be like a B-rated movie.  However, I stuck with it, and became very absorbed by the plot within 30 minutes.  The lead character, Adam, played perfectly by Ben Bonenfant (do watch his great commentary in Features), is a sociopathic hustler (aren't all good hustlers sociopaths?).  He morphs his behavior as he meets one person or group of persons after another in the same building, all to impress them and make some bucks with his good looks and sex.  But surprising and touching events begin to happen along the way.  Some great pulls on heartstrings here.This movie makes me think of a mashup between "Where The Day Takes You" (compare Dermot Mulroney's character, King, with Ben Bonenfant's character, Adam) with a young man trying to control his life and the movie "Four Rooms," which has multiple stories within one building.After submitting this review, I am most definitely going to look for more of actor Ben Bonenfant's and writer/director Joseph Graham's work.  And THANKS to all of you who wrote previous reviews that influenced me to buy this movie.

reviewText: Lots of "gay" movies are enjoyable just for the gay themes, etc. This was such a good movie- I felt a bit like a stalker but I looked up Ben Bonenfant to see what other movies he has been in.... That explains the dialogue and the way he spoke.It was also such a refreshing catalog of characters- each very different but their differences were treated with respect- Funny how a movie about a hustler and his tricks is really a story about people....I didn't rent this movie for a long time because of the title but I am so glad I finally did. Rent this movie or even buy this movie.

reviewText: An astonishing, spectacularly good little movie - much, MUCH better than anybody has words to say. Sexy and poetic, lyrical and heartbreaking and soaring. It is as mundane as a leaking roof and as wide and glorious as the universe. To say it is about a hustler turning tricks is like saying the Odyssey is about a guy who got stuck in traffic on the way home.Its minor flaws, so tiny they are almost insignificant - sloppy camera focus in crucial scenes, occasionally ponderous dialog, the total lack of tongues during the all-important kiss - simply make it better, realer, more human, as tiny flaws in great works of art always do.If I could have seen only one gay movie in all my life, this is the one I would want it to be.

reviewText: I saw strapped at Reeling, Chicago's Gay and Lesbian Film Festival, and it was among the best movies I've seen in the past year.  The performances were uniformly solid, and Ben Bonenfant, the lead, turned in a truly spectacular performance.  His timing and delivery are spot on, and his performance is uncommonly honest.  The character is, by turns, cunning, seductive, cynical, vulnerable, and childlike.Strapped is a sexy film, but it portrays sex as far more than a one-dimensional hormonal impulse; sex in this movie is a commodity, a power exchange, a form of nurturing, and a human interaction of vast complexity and myriad purposes.  Strapped is (and you'll understand this when you see it) simultaneously dark and heartwarming in a way that I've never seen in a film before.Surprisingly, this film reminded me of two mainstream films that I saw years ago, Jacob's Ladder and Siesta, but the ending is different and far more engaging than either of those films.If you like smart, edgy gay drama, then this is a great film for you.  The artistry of this film is extraordinary; the writing is tight, the acting is excellent, and the directing is masterful.I'll be seeing this film several times.

reviewText: This film immediately reminded me of Greek Mythology. Our young hero begins a journey and visits many "chambers" (if you will allow) observing, feeling, beginning to understand many things of life. The life of a young hustler is difficult at best, certainly fear of sharing ones life with others is a common occurrence. In truth the world is a difficult and fearful place to live in. Our hero observes various people who seem to be trapped in a world they cannot leave. I rented this film first and have recently purchased it. I am sure it will be one I watch with some frequency in order to view the world from a different perspective.

He visits various residents of a single apartment building, drawn in each time by one thing or another, each encounter resulting in a meaningful, memorable, and even therapeutic event.  The story--or stories--is not complex yet I find myself thinking about it again and again in the several months since I viewed it, and I plan to watch it again one of these day.  I highly recommend it.

reviewText: Writer/director Joseph Graham presents a new notch on the hustler genre belt. The hustler film probably started in 1950's Sunset BLVD, with William Holden servicing Swanson's Norma Desmond. In the early 60's Tennessee Williams had two gigolo films (Sweet Smell of Success and The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone),and one featured, briefly, a male prostitute with his male client, admiring his new gift ring. Nineteen sixty nine, a good year for sex in the cinema, saw the template for the current gay hustler story, Midnight Cowboy.Since Joe Buck sauntered along the New York streets, the hustler film rivals the coming out film in Queer Cinema as subject matter. Andy Warhol's Flesh, Mala Noche,My Own Private Idaho, johns, Sex Life in L.A., Hustler White,Live for Sex Die for Love, Mysterious Skin, Sugar, Twist, Boy Culture, Men for Sale, End Game,and In the Flesh to name a few, and that's not including the foreign language imports like Our Lady of the Assassins, Clandestinos, Bulgarian Lovers, and The Blue Hour.Strapped takes this cliched character and makes him a realistic, likable creation with one objective: get paid, get out. What turns this mercenary character sympathetic is that he's literally trapped, makes the best of a bad situation, and shows empathy to all his clients. Trapped in a Kafka like maze of hallways, the unnamed boy (although he pretends to be various names)seems to be meet every personification of the gay scene: coming out, drug addiction, denial, homophobia, even love.Director Graham, with his production team and camera operator, manage to take this Twilight Zone-like tale, and make the most of a low budget. Every shot is clear and visually interesting. The repetitive nature of the story stays intriguing up to the satisfying climax. Actor Ben Bonenfant's rentboy is handsome in an average boy-next-door way, and wisely underplays his role with a cunning vulnerability.  This one is worth buying. The movie too.
summary: Strapped for cash, redeemed by experience

reviewText: When the character's not finding the door is a plot device in a thoughtful and well-written script, something bigger is happening. You know the plot by now, so consider this when you watch. Especially all those who found the plot not too likely or a little too predictable.Eddie, whose name changes to fit each customer, takes money losing himself in being anyone's fantasy. When the show's over, he moves on, before the illusion is spoiled. Despite the comprehensive intimacy of this work, he retains something of himself behind walls that he lets nobody breach. If one of the stories he tells is true, that tender secret part is hideously damaged and a natural reason for him to have become a hustler.Just consider that maybe seeing this story as allegory is not too far off track. Because more than just being an honest version of Pretty Woman, this movie's humanistic approach hints at love of great books and their ideas. That's likely the source for the great rewards attributed to its viewing.This beautiful rich creation brings hope that gays will refuse third-rate treatment from crappy gay film-makers just as they refuse to be treated less well in other areas. If it weren't bigoted to say, I'd suggest that this is the gay film one reasonably expects all the time, given the stereotype of gays being extremely creative, talented, and discerning [not too mention good-looking.]

reviewText: Maybe it's just me, but this movie is one that has stuck with me since I'd first seen it. Ben Bonenfant, while not being physically perfect, brings an electricity to this part that obviously attracts both his cutomers and his viewers.  The encounters tend to cover the big four of gay sexual acts, so I was curious as to what would be repeated for the fifth scene.  I think writers found an excellent way to bring us full circle and then take us out of it.There have been quite a few movies that have stuck with for a long time (although I will confess that very few have be LGBT oriented): The History Boys, The Outsiders, Mysterious Skin, and American Beauty.  I guess my overall list is a bit esoteric, but Strapped is certainly on my list.  I think you'll enjoy it.

This is a film I would think everyone from late teen to any age adult could enjoy, simply for its quality and acting. The gay sex is minimal. Mostly implied. It plays a small part in the film. Its the plot, charters and acting that makes this film a MUST SEE. On the same level as BrokeBack Mountain. A masterpiece!!! A Must see film!!!

reviewText: It's amazing how some of the best movies in any given year have been accomplished on very low budgets, but through sheer craft and artistry, easily best 99% of Hollywood productions.  Strapped is a case in point.  The lead character, a young male hustler, services a client in a non-descript urban apartment complex.  Strangely, he seems unable to find his way out of the Kafkaesque building, repeatedly running into different sorts of gay males who want to sample his wares.  Each of the successive clients seems to represent a different pathway of the gay lifestyle, posing many questions and conundrums along the way.  Some are ridiculously closeted, stuck in false, married lives.  Some are very liberated, but strangely unhappy.  Different sexual tastes are contrasted: aggressive, anal passive, bizarre things.  In the end the protagonist overcomes his own gay demons by allowing himself true romantic affection, perhaps.  The symbolism reminds me of the fine poem by Henri Cole, entitled Homosexuality, where the gay life is symbolized as a duck stuck in a chimney!The great strength of Strapped lay in its fine dialogue and characterization.  The script is dotted with literary and poetic allusions and various gay homages.  The fantastic artistry is made evident by more than just the frame trope of the labyrinth, but also much other symbolism and subtext along the way.  For instance, the metallic griffin stolen from the first client seems to symbolize sexual liberation.  There is some fine directing skill at work too.  In one scene, their is a vessel put to trap leaking rain water, and the elapsement of time is shown by empty and full shots.  Most importantly, the lead actor is exceedingly loveable.The only negative I might find about the movie is some of the graphic sexual content, but I guess that comes with the territory.  Plus a sort of goofy poem in the last scene.  Altogether, Strapped is a charming, thoughtful movie that should be watched by anyone who is gay or simply curious about alternative lifestyles.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As the mom of a gay man, I enjoy watching gay themed films (with or without him by my side). This film was so awesome and blew me away. I was expecting another stereotypical film with a bunch of good looking men and boys partying and having sex...with a lame message. The title threw me off at first, but I was so glad I watched it. The lead actor was adorable and very sexy in a rather non-obviously gay persona. The people he encounters throughout his journey in the apartment building serve to teach him something about himself as he provides each one with something they desperately crave. It is sad, funny, sexy and thought provoking all at the same time. I plan to watch it again (this time with my son)...it was THAT good. Kudos to a great script and a director who really drew strong emotion from his actors without coming across as preachy or over the top dramatic. A strong but at times sweet story for anyone with an open mind!
summary: LOVED this film...and I am a mom =)

reviewText: Emotional and uplifting without being preachy or sappy, "Strapped" is a wonderful exploration of the differences, and more importantly, the similarities and needs within us all. And FYI, damned sexy too. A definite must see.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great journeys can take place in confined spaces.  It isn't about how far one travels but how much one discovers.Strapped is about self discovery within the confines of an apartment building.  The main character is a gay male hustler who probably finds little value in himself other than an ability to make money.  Yet in his quest to make money he gets to hear some incredible comments.  The hustler asks his first john, "How do you feel?"  The john answers "I feel free."  WOW, what an incredible ability the hustler has.  It isn't just about the sex.By the end of the film, the hustler has a request not for sex, but a request to touch someone's soul by sharing a kiss.  Again, WOW.  I think by this point the hustler is realizing he is more than just an agent of desire.  In the end, the hustler is the one whose soul has been touched.This film is amazingly simple, touching, well acted and rich with so many thought provoking ideas.

reviewText: Unusual title and an unusual film. This stars Ben Bonenfant in the title role and for a hustler he comes across (forgive the pun) as a real 'tart with a heart'.The plot is quite simple in that a random or should I say routine 'trick' takes our eponymous hero back to his apartment for gay sex. He is a gay virgin and this hustler treats him with real humanity and care. He then finds it very hard to actually exit the building -and in his endeavours to escape finds rather more 'entrances' than is technically necessary in any film outside the porn genre.All that said it should come (there I go again) as no surprise as this apartment turns out to be the gayest apartment block on the gayest street in town- well when in Rome and all that. Even the straight guys turn out to want a bit of Ben and it is not always the same bit, which I think from a plot development point of view is necessary as seriously doing it that many times in such a short space of time would challenge even a Viagra addict to 'keep up' as it were.It is as I said a simple plot but what is strikingly brilliant is the breadth and depth of the characters that he meets and the humanity that unfolds in every story or occurrence, he is almost a social worker, that is one that charges an agreed fee before giving a full service. It is a warm, witty, charming, human and sometimes raunchy film but told and acted with real care and in many ways heart warming because of and not despite the regular sexual trysts.
summary: Strapped means to sell your body for cash (for non US types as it is not that in the UK)

reviewText: This film exploits every gay stereotype.  It narrates a very long night in the life of a street whore. Stuck in a building where he can't find the exit but finds himself at the end- oh pleeeaaassse! Every guy he encounters is only interested in his decease infected orifice(s).  But wait, you discover he also has a heart, and so does every character he encounters.  The acting and script is very poor and predictable.However, the philosophical idea of the film is interesting. It's worth renting- if all the other good movies have been rented- and of course this one is still on the shelf...
summary: A whore with a heart of gold
